title: Georgia House - Day 17 (2026-02-16)
summary:
Overview:
The session included a prayer by Reverend Anthony Motley, who emphasized the importance of pledging allegiance to the higher authority of the Constitution and country, not just partisan political interests. He highlighted examples of public officials like Liz Cheney and Brad Raffensperger who demonstrated this higher loyalty during the January 6th events.

Key Actions: 
None detected.

Bills Introduced (First Reading):
None detected.

Notable Moments:
- Reverend Motley's sermon emphasized the need for legislators to transcend partisan divides and act in the greater good of the country. 
- He praised officials like Liz Cheney and Brad Raffensperger who upheld their loyalty to the Constitution over partisan pressure during the January 6th events.
- Reverend Motley called on legislators to choose "a higher loyalty" over lower political interests.

Votes:
None detected.

Attendance:
No specific quorum notes.

Adjournment:
The transcript does not mention an adjournment time or the next session date.

We will begin our day with scripture reading and prayer by the chaplain, after which we will pledge allegiance to the flag of our country. Our chaplain this morning will be introduced by the lady from the 56th House District Representative Misha Maynard, representative Maynard. Thank you, Speaker. Its oldest member is mother Savannah Williams. She is 102 years old. The church is located in my district in the English Avenue neighborhood, which is very close to the Mercedes-Benz stadium. The recognizes for a morning order, Chairman Bonnie Rich. We're going to have one minute each for morning orders today. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. This on the screen is Henry Smith with his grandchildren at our local Welfel House in Swanee for their Christmas morning tradition. Henry was a devoted grandfather and husband and he had a goal to live to 100. He faithfully saw his doctors and took his medicine. He was mentally alert and living well when he became sick and he was hospitalized shortly. Unfortunately, he was separated at the door from his family and he was alone and scared. This once confident World War II veteran began calling his son fearful about what was happening to him. He didn't understand. He wanted his son to come be with him and when that couldn't happen, he asked his son to come get him. On the ride to home, he told his son that this hospital's day was one of the worst things that had ever happened to him. Days later, when he got into trouble, his home nurse pleaded with him to go back to the hospital, but he said he would never go back, that he didn't want to relive what he had experienced before. He chose to stay home and be with his family rather than to seek treatment because he didn't want to be separated from them. The time for this to stop has come. Thank you. Chair recognizes representative Bernal for a morning order. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. A March 2nd, we will celebrate Dr. Susan's birthday known as Read Across America Day. In honor of that day, I'm asking that each of us record ourselves reading a Dr. Susan's book and send it to the elementary schools in your district to be shared with the students on March 2nd. I am also asking that members in the house celebrate that day by the men wearing red tie or bow tie and the ladies wearing red and white. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Chair recognizes representative Moore for a morning order. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. As we observed President's Day yesterday in the middle of Black History Month, I wanted to share my favorite memory in recent history that combines the two. You see on September 12th, 2019, I watched as 26 members of the Georgia Legislative Black Caucus publish a letter in support of the man who would eventually become the 46th President of the United States. Now remember this was in the middle of a crowded field. There was no clear front runner at the time. And admittedly I'd hitched my wagon to a different candidate. But these 26 members of this legislative body had the wisdom to know that experience matters. The foresight to pick a winner out of a crowded field and the leadership to put their name on the line for the man who had become the leader of our party, our state, and our country. So I want to celebrate these members and thank them for their leadership. Chair recognizes representative Scott for a morning order. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. From one female veteran to another, I salute you today. We served in the Army, Air Force, Navy, Marines, Coast Guard, Army reserves, and National Guard. We fought in all the wars and we are still fighting today. Women veterans in this great state, I salute you today. I had the honor of recognizing Nancy Gail Hemp, Jacqueline Perry, Blade Lock, and Better Turner to all the women veterans in this great state of Georgia. I salute you today. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Chair recognizes representative Scott Field for a morning order. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I am a black woman, although the nation honors black history for one month, I am proud of my history 365 days strong. Today I present Alice Coachman. Alice Coachman became the first black woman from any country to win a gold medal in track and field. Coachman had come from a poor background in Albany, Georgia, and due to segregation, she was restricted, had restricted access to top quality training facilities and was also often denied the opportunity to train for or compete in organized sporting events. However, that didn't stop her from continuing to develop her strengths and talents. Coachman ran barefoot on dirt roads and used old equipment to train. Then she was taken under the wing of the boys track coach at Madison High School, Harry E. Lash, who recognized her talents. She broke high school and college AAU track records for track and field barefoot. In 1939, she received a scholarship at the age of 16 to Tuskegee Institute in Tuskegee, Alabama. As she continued to dominate the AAU competitions, in 1946, she enrolled in Albany State College. She won the national champion in the 50 and 100 meters races as well as the 400 meter relay and high jump. Despite her back industry, engineering, Coachman set a record for the high jump with a mark of five feet, six and one eighth inches, making her the first black women to win an Olympic gold medal. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I leave you with this word that she said, her quote is, and I grabbed it to my heart. I paid the way for them all. Alice Coachman. Thank you. Chair recognizes representative Derek Jackson for a morning order. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Founded 112 years ago on February 12, 1909, the National Association for Advancement of Color People was formed. It is the nation's foremost largest and most widely recognized civil rights organization. It has over 500,000 members and supporters, and this organization continues to fight the good fight to ensure that this true aim that it was created for. And it was created for all people, the rights guaranteed in the 13th, 14th and 15th amendments to the United States Constitution, which promised to end to slavery and the equal protection under law, under the law. The NAACP is a great example when we all come together. Nearly 60 Americans came together, whites and blacks to fight a common cause. And that is a true moment of black history. House Bill 254, Representative Lomston of the 12th and others being tied on knack to a menarch on 1 on chapter 23, a title 33 of the fiscal to George Anaceta relating the licensing of agencies, sub-agents, counselors, and adjusters. This bill I refer to the Committee on Insurance Committee recommends that this bill do pass by Committee substitute. Chair recognizes the Chair of the House Insurance Committee. Chairman Lomston to present the bill. Reporting Mr. Speaker, members of the House, I bring to you House Bill 254. This is a department bill that comes as a priority request from the insurance commissioner. House Bill 254 addresses the laws governing the operation of public adjusters in our state. Whenever an insured person files a claim for a law, an insurance adjuster is involved in investigating and coordinating settlement of the claims. Larger companies may use a company adjuster while smaller companies often use a public adjuster. In a natural disaster such as a hurricane or tornado, public adjusters play an important role for many people. Most public adjusters are professional and perform a valuable service in helping those who have suffered loss to obtain repairs and coordinate settlement of their claim. However public adjusters are one of the most consistent sources of consumer fraud. The Georgia Department of Insurance deals with every year, costing consumers millions of dollars. The majority of this fraud is aimed at the elderly, the disabled, or those who are in the most need after a natural disaster. This has been a common problem in most coastal states for many years because like Georgia, they deal with natural disasters and have laws governing the operation of public adjusters that are broad and lacking in specifics. House Bill 254 changes Georgia's public adjuster law to align with similar changes made in Florida as well as Texas, both states that deal with natural disasters and public adjusters. The changes include new licensing requirements, higher standards of conduct, introduces new consumer protections, governs how a public adjuster can present themselves, requires the use of department-approved contracts, specifically bans the public adjusters from serving in multiple capacities, specifically from serving as a contractor as well as the appraiser. It gives the department the authority to adopt rules and regulations necessary to implement this legislation. Mr. Speaker, that is the bill. I'll be glad to answer any questions if there are any.
